intro: Commiphora lacerata, commonly known as the African frankincense tree, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to eastern and southern Africa. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes other resin-producing plants such as frankincense and myrrh. The plant is characterized by its smooth, greyish bark and opposite, ovate leaves with serrated edges. It produces a fragrant resin, which has been historically used in traditional medicine and as a perfume. The plant thrives in dry, well-drained soils and is often found in savanna and woodland habitats.
